ygData.subject: cantera matlab toolbox
ygData.msgSnippet: Mathiew, I think there is a README file that explains what to do.  I know there is in the source distribution, but I might have left it out of the Windows

Mathiew,

I think there is a README file that explains what to do.  I know
=
there is in the source 
distribution, but I might have left it out of the W=
indows installer.

In any case, run Cantera14.msi, then you will have a fol=
der named
Cantera, and within 
that should be a folder named Matlab. In the=
re is a zip file that is
the Matlab toolbox. 
Unzip it, start Matlab, and a=
dd it to the Matlab  path.

It is possible if you are running Windows 98 th=
at your system does
not have the 
Windows Installer, which you need to run =
.msi files.  If it doesn't
run, go to the 
Microsoft web site and search fo=
r 'Windows Installer'.
(This is standard on Windows 2000 or later, and is a=
lso installed
automatically if you 
install Microsoft Office 2000 on older =
systems.)

Hope this helps.

Dave Goodwin

ll be 
welcome.
> Thank you very much.
> Mathiew

> On Monday, April 21, 2003, at 07:=
16 AM, David Goodwin wrote:
> 
> > Cantera 1.4 has been released.
> >
> > W=
hat's new:
> >
> > 1. Simplified unix build procedure. Cantera should build=
 'out of
the
> > box' on linux, cygwin, Mac OS X, and Solaris. If you have =
Python
and/or
> > MATLAB installed, the appropriate interface will be built=
 and
installed
> > automatically. You can choose the installation directory=
.
> >
> > 2. As of this release, Cantera is now hosted by SourceForge at
> =
> http://sourceforge.net/projects/cantera. You can access the
current
> > v=
ersion of the source through the read-only CVS server, or
download the
> > =
latest release as a tar.gz archive.
> >
> > 3. Fortran 77 support.  A compl=
ete example is included of using
Cantera
> > from Fortran 77. See file 'f77=
.doc' in the 'cantera documentation'
> > package at the SourceForge site.
>=
 >
> > A Windows version will be released shortly.
> >

gs, comments, suggestions, etc. either here or

 SourceForge Cantera site.
